verses.text: The woman Folly is loud; she is undisciplined and without knowledge.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9
rsbNotes.text: 9:1–18 This section consists of two competing invitations, one from wisdom and the other from folly. Both are portrayed as women calling people to enter their houses. Wisdom invites the simple to eat of her life-giving food (vv. 1–12). Folly offers food that leads to death (vv. 13–18).

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9:13–18
rsbNotes.text: 9:13–18 The description of folly is directly opposed to that of wisdom in vv. 1–6.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9:13
rsbNotes.text:
9:13 loud. See 7:11, 12.

seductive and knows nothing. The sensuous appeal of folly contrasts with wisdom as the teacher.

verses.text: She sits at the door of her house, on a seat at the highest point of the city,

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9:14
rsbNotes.text: 9:14 on the highest places of the town. Folly counterfeits the actions of wisdom so as to appear wise (cf. v. 3).

verses.text: calling out to those who pass by, who go straight on their way.
"Let all who are simple come in here!" she says to those who lack judgment.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9:15–16
rsbNotes.text: 9:15, 16 Folly’s entreaties further imitate those of wisdom (cf. v. 4).

verses.text: "Stolen water is sweet; food eaten in secret is delicious!"

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9:17
rsbNotes.text:
9:17 Stolen water. Anything that is forbidden, especially illicit sex (5:3, 15; 7:16–18).

bread eaten in secret. Because it is stolen or forbidden. There is a perversity in human nature that is stirred up by prohibition and the law (Rom. 7:7–11).

verses.text: But little do they know that the dead are there, that her guests are in the depths of the grave.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 9:18
rsbNotes.text:
9:18 the dead. Hebrew rephaim, of uncertain derivation. The word is used eight times in the Bible, all in Hebrew poetry, referring to the spirits of the departed.

Sheol. Lit. “the grave.” See 1:12; 5:5; 7:27 and notes. In Proverbs, Sheol is the fitting destination of fools not because it is a place of torment, as Hell is later described (Rev. 14:9–11), but simply because those who go there have lost the possibility of relationship with the living God. See also 2:18 and note.
